start.title: Sweet Country
start.creator_credit: Warwick Thornton, Heather Wallace, David Jowsey, Greer Simpkin, Bunya Productions, Tony Cronin, David Tranter and Steven McGregor
start.brief_description: It’s 1929 on the vast, desert-like, Eastern Arrernte Nation lands that are now known as the Central Australian outback. Sam Kelly, a middle-aged Aboriginal man, works the land of a kind preacher, Fred Smith. After an ill-tempered bully arrives in town and Kelly kills him in self-defence, he and his wife go on the run as a posse gathers to hunt him down.

constellations_primary.name: Sweet Country
constellations_primary.description: Warwick Thornton’s feature film Sweet Country is based on the story of Wilaberta Jack, which was told to sound recordist David Tranter by his grandfather and translated into storyboards.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

end.title: The Story of the Kelly Gang

end.brief_description: Produced in Melbourne in 1906, The Story of the Kelly Gang is the world’s first feature-length film. While most movies of its era only ran for about 12 minutes, Charles Tait’s bushranger epic went for over an hour.

links.description: Sweet Country‘s Sam Kelly is condemned by the same white townsfolk who idolise another outlaw, Ned Kelly. The 1906 film The Story of the Kelly Gang is screened in the town in the same spot where Sam stands trial.
